REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 5 Report of the State Auditor State of Nebraska AUDITOR S OFFICE To Hor R. McKelvie rnor of Nebraska <;. My dear I take pleasure in submitting my rdanee with Statute 4847 port h rewith, covering the period from December 1, 1920 to June In my previous report, I made a number of recommendations per- hods affecting state accounting, most of which hav n enacted into law by the legislature. Foremost among the changes hange of the fiscal year. The Nebraska fiscal year now runs was June 30th, corresponding with the Federal year; .y Treasurers make settlement with the state on July 1st nsidered the close of the annual tax collection port covers the receipts and expenditures for the fiscal year June 30. 1922, this being the first full year re rted on the new basis. A separate report is made of the seven month December 1, 1920 to June 30, 1921 Outcome of Operations your attention to Statement No. 2, Revenues and ge 38) where the governmental cost for the last 62.51 is set up against the revenues belonging to an excess of Revenues over Governmental cost In addition there was an increase to the permanent 2^;.tHx.ys :atements pertaining to receipts and disbursements in red in accordance with the methods used by the Federal Department of Commerce in compiling their biennial "Statistics of However, in the supporting schedules to Statement No. 2 the receipts are further itemized showing the sources of revenue and by whom collected and similarly the expenditures are shown according to the expending agencies on pages 51 to 54 and in de ages 133 to 150. :i A condensed summary of the Governmental Cost Expenditures for the fiscal year 1921-22 shows the following Operating Expenses, Aids, etc % 6,878,126.05 Public Improvements (Roads and Bridges) 3,242,059.06 Capital Outlay— Property acquired 1.181,40756 Capital Outlay— Bonds purchased (Soldiers Relief) 236,000.00 Appropriated Funds Expended $11,537,592.37 Temporary School and Forest Reserve Fund receipts distributed 1,038,670.14 Total $12,576,262.51

6 REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Of the receipts nearly two-thirds or $9,662,863.52 are represented by Property taxes received from counties, $1,477,459.56 was received from the U. S. Government, and the balance $3,992,534.64 is made up of Land Lease Money, Interest collected, receipts from Institutions, and Revenues collected by the departments. The resources of the state now total $64,717,423.15, as shown in detail on Statement No. 1. There is no bonded indebtedness as far as the state proper is concerned, but the counties and subdivisions con - tinue to issue bonds at an ever increasing rate. Indebtedness of Subdivisions To call attention to the tendency of the subdivision of the state to rely upon the issuance of bonds and to enable an intelligent survey, I have prepared Statement No. 11 showing the indebtedness by counties including their subdivisions such as municipalities, school districts, etc., with the population and the assessed valuation of the separate counties. The bonded indebtedness of the counties of the state including their subdivisions now totals $73,760,187.00, ranging from $23,721,907.00 for Douglas County inclusive to $1,000.00 for Thomas County. The average for all counties inclusive is $793,120.02. The average per capita indebtedness is $56.90, and the average per mill indebtedness figures $22.26 per $1,000.00 assessed valuation. The following have a bonded indebtedness exceeding tw dollars : Douglas County, including subdivisions Lancaster County, including subdivision Scotts Bluff County, including subdivision I The following counties have a per capita indebtedness exceeding Registration of Bonds During the 19 months covered by this report, the total amount of bonds registered at the State Auditor's office was $24,557,318.00. This H 00.00: harden County, including subdivisions $128.80 Douglas County, including subdivisions 115.98 Dawes County, including subdivisions 114.39 Scotts Bluff County, including subdivisions 112.81 The greatest per mill indebtedness meaning amount of bonds issued 'or each $1,000.00 assessed valuation is in the following counties: 5cotts Bluff County, including subdivisions $72.63 Douglas County, including subdivisions 66.31 Dawes County, including subdivisions 57.81 Jox Butte County, including subdivisions 50.91 Horrill County, including subdivisions 43.48 jiarden County, including subdivisions 42.95 led Willow County, including subdivisions 36.67 Lancaster County, including subdivisions , 29.10

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 7 is a large increase as compared with former years, as shown by the Registering so many more bonds does not only put upon the State Auditor's office a lot of additional work, looking up the bond his - tories, conducting correspondence, etc., but it also considerably in - creases the expense; to mention only the item of postage, returning the bonds to the districts by first-class mail and registered, is costly. Many comparisons of the present cost of the state government as against former years have been made lately. When the duties and the work put upon a department are increased — as they have been increased in the Bond Department nearly fourfold within the last four years, the expenses will increase also. The only way to avoid placing additional burdens upon the taxpayers is to make those issuing the pay the cost of registering. I therefore repeat my recommendation that a charge of ten cents ■>e made for each bond registered, payable to the State Auditor, the money to be turned into the State Treasury to become available for the payment of postage and expense of the State Auditor's department. Fees on Tax Collections In my previous report I expressed myself in favor of the abolish - ment of the special levies, recommending fixed appropriations out of the General Fund instead. The 1921 Legislature abolished most of the special levies increas - ing the General Fund levy and making appropriations particularly for the educational institutions out of the General Fund. It now re - mains to adjust the rate of fees paid to the County Treasurers. The old law (2439 — 1913 Statutes) allows only \ c ,'c on all school moneys collected, while the rate on General Fund collections runs from 2'i up. This law was not changed and the state is now paying annually a little over \1< more for the collection of the taxes needed for the support of the University and the Normal Schools. The annual appro - priations for these institutions out of the General Fund will run about $1,850,000.00 for the University, and $650,000.00 for the four Normal schools, a total of about two and a half million dollars per year, repre - senting a yearly increase in the collection cost to the state of about $30,000.00. It would therefore seem the proper thing to change the rate of fees so as to equalize matters and the change should preferably affect only the treasurers in the larger counties. following: o Bonds Period Registered 24 mo. Dec. 1, 1916 to Nov. 30, 1918 % 7,651.488.10 24 mo. Dec. 1, 1918 to Nov. 30, 1920 22,124,089.52 19 mo. Dec. 1, 1920 to June 30, 1922 24,567,318.00 Average per Month $318,953.00 921337.00 1,293,016.00 Increased Expense of Bond Division

8 REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS The treasurers in the smaller counties are depending upon their fees and in the smaller counties the fees heretofore have perhaps hardly yielded a sufficient remuneration. In the larger counties there are always excess fees to be turned into the County General Fund, and here the fees might be reduced, without causing loss to the treasurer or any particular disadvantage to the taxpayers of the county. I would suggest that on all above $200,000.00 the fee be reduced to Wilt. Then, where a county treasurer collects annually from $230,000.00 to $250,000.00 there would be virtually no change in the rate of fees under the proposed arrangement as against prior years. Those collecting more than $250,000.00 would have their fees reduced somewhat and the amounts thus saved to the state in the larger counties would counterbalance the loss caused through increased fees being paid to the treasurers in the smaller counties. However, it would be still better to entirely abolish the payment of collection fees to County Treasurers, each county to pay to its treasurer out of the General Fund a salary fixed in accordance with the population or the assessed valuation of the respective county. This is now successfully being done in the states of Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, North Dakota and South Dakota. During the last fiscal year the collection fees paid by the s to the county treasurers for the collection of state taxes averaged 2.: and amounted to $220,267.34. If no collection fee had to be paid state levy might be reduced to correspond. The abolishment of lection fees would simplify the accounting not only for the state also for each county and would not at all affect the taxpayers, ex as there would be some saving in accounting cost, which finally w revert to the taxpayers. Unclaimed and Outstanding Warrant The business of the state is ever increasing and the number of warrants issued. Quite a few warrants are not presented for pay - ment promptly, and there are on hand some warrants that could not be delivered and remain unclaimed. This makes difficult at any time the determination of the exact amount of warrants outstanding. I would suggest that a law be passed, requiring all state warrants to be cashed within one year and providing that warrants not presented for payment at the State Treasurer within one year from date of issue shall be paid only by special direction of the State Auditor. With such a law all warrants outstanding for over a year might then be eliminated from the warrant account and transferred to unclaimed warrants payable. Examination of County Officers In my previous report I called attention to the law (Chapter 73. 1919) requiring all* books, accounts and affairs of all county offices in

I have therefore employed but two county an endeavor to at least make a thorough check es once every two years. :ient appropriations the law above cited remains JtrRt'st that the law be amended so as to give ;he choice of either employing public accountants ns u exan .f by the direction and under the supervision \v Auditor, the county in either case to bear all cost and i a law were passed, no appropriation would be needed •evolving fund to start the work. Then as collections exp the amounts collected should be deposited Treasurer to reimburse the revolving fund. Thus the be carried on without any expense to the state. The State Duld be authorized to employ accountants as needed, paying salaries as may be necessary to secure competent men, the w A he counties to be at the rate of $10.00 per day and ex- L'l A which is respectfully submitted GEO. W. MARSH, Auditor Public Accounts. House, Lincoln, Nebraska July, 1922.
